alert.note: Alert for Oxford (Maine) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 30 at 11:12PM EDT until May 01 at 11:07PM EDT by NWS Gray/Portland
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in New Hampshire... Pemigewasset River At Woodstock affecting Grafton County. Pemigewasset River At Plymouth affecting Belknap and Grafton Counties. Suncook River At North Chichester affecting Belknap and Merrimack Counties. ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Maine... New Hampshire... Saco River At Conway affecting Cumberland, Oxford and Carroll Counties. Swift River At Roxbury affecting Oxford County. For the Pemigewasset River...including Woodstock, Plymouth...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Saco River...including Conway, West Buxton...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Swift River...including Roxbury...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Suncook River...including North Chichester...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TOMORROW EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Swift River at Roxbury. * WHEN...Until late tomorrow evening. * IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, Minor lowland flooding begins. At 9.0 feet, Flood waters inundate Route 17 in Byron near the intersection of Byron Village Road. At 10.0 feet, Closure of Route 17 likely from flood waters, significantly impacting travel in and out of the area. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:30 PM EDT Sunday the stage was 4.2 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage just after midnight tonight to 11.0 feet tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow afternoon to 3.5 feet early Tuesday afternoon. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/gray.
